#Text=Golden Week holidays in China
#Text=The Golden Week holidays in China fall in January or February , as well as October .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The Golden Week holidays are popular times for holiday travel ; despite significantly higher rates , trains , flights , and hotels are often fully booked .
#Text=Popular sites for visitors will be busier during the Golden Week holidays .
#Text=The People 's Republic of China observes two golden weeks each year :
#Text=The Chinese New Year Golden Week begins in January or February .
#Text=This is the more important golden week , with hundreds of millions of people going back to their hometowns to spend time with family , and many others taking trips as tourists .
#Text=This is the largest annual human migration in the world .
#Text=Many people have additional time off beyond the Golden Week , which means that the associated travel season lasts 40 days , from 15 days before Chinese New Year to 25 days after .
#Text=For those 40 days , transportation will be extremely crowded and tickets may be hard to come by , even if you book well in advance .
#Text=This is especially true for trains , whereas flights are not affected as much .
#Text=2019
#Text=New Year : Feb 5 ; holiday : Feb 4 - 10 ; travel rush Jan 21 - Mar 1
#Text=2020
#Text=New Year : Jan 25 ; holiday : Jan 24 - 30
#Text=2021
#Text=New Year : Feb 12 ; holiday : Feb 11 - 17
#Text=The National Day Golden Week begins 1 October each year , and lasts until Oct 7 ( or Oct 8 , depending on weekends ) .
#Text=Official estimates are that 700 million people travel during this period — that 's close to half of China 's population !
#Text=( This does include some double counting as one person can take two trips . )
#Text=For each golden week , the country observes three days of paid national holidays , and the surrounding weekends are rearranged to give workers seven days off in a row .
#Text=Schools and individual companies may take additional days off .
#Text=China takes steps to cope with the pressure put on its transport system , such as by increasing train services and suspending tolls .
#Text=Expect long vehicle queues on expressways linking big cities , and line-ups at gas stations .
#Text=Travel time on buses can triple , and some runs may be cancelled because of highway congestion .
#Text=Also , expect queues at popular tourist attractions , and restaurants and hotels will be extremely busy .
#Text=Travel tips
#Text=If possible , avoid traveling to China during a Golden Week .
#Text=If you ca n't help it , consider the following tips to manage your trip :
#Text=1. Make your reservations early .
#Text=This includes reserved train seating , airline tickets , hotels , and tours .
#Text=2. Allow extra time for travel .
#Text=You may encounter long lines or delays .
#Text=Be sure to allow extra time to accommodate any delays .
#Text=3. Enjoy what 's local .
#Text=One way to beat the crowds is to avoid using the highways , public transportation , and tourist attractions .
#Text=Instead , plan to pursue activities within walking distance of your accommodation .
#Text=Other countries
#Text=Countries near China see an influx of tourists at this time as well , as both expats in China and well-to-do Chinese citizens take advantage of the time off to go on vacation .
#Text=Hong Kong and Macau are popular destinations for mainlanders .
#Text=People in China visiting another country often visit Thailand , Japan , and the US .
#Text=Outside of greater China , other countries with large ethnic Chinese populations have celebrations for Chinese New Year , including Malaysia and Singapore .
#Text=In these countries , some businesses will be closed and travel may be hectic , though the disruption wo n't be nearly as bad as in China .
#Text=See also
#Text=Golden Week in Japan
